head.title: New Terrorism Bill Protects Civil Rights

hedline.hl1: New Terrorism Bill Protects Civil Rights

block.p: Anthony Lewis aptly summarizes the threats to our constitutional rights that are rampant in the antiterrorism bill to be considered by the House of Representatives this week ("How Terrorism Wins," column, March 11).

Anthony Lewis aptly summarizes the threats to our constitutional rights that are rampant in the antiterrorism bill to be considered by the House of Representatives this week ("How Terrorism Wins," column, March 11).

The bill would, in fact, do little to insure "public safety," but would severely threaten civil liberties. We would add, however, that Congress is not necessarily forced to choose between fighting terrorism and protecting our civil liberties; in fact, we can do both.

We have introduced a substitute to this legislation that is tougher on terrorism and includes stronger protections for United States citizens who are victims of violence in terrorist states. Our substitute omits provisions of the bill that are constitutionally suspect and unrelated to the problem of terrorism.
The need for a comprehensive antiterrorism bill is acute, but one that is rendered unenforceable is nothing more than a charade intended to make Congress look tough on terrorism.
JOHN CONYERS JR . JERROLD NADLER House Judiciary Committee Washington, March 11, 1996
